repnme.cdata!:
Sri Lanka - First Poverty Reduction Support
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, and modest institutional
            development impacts, including satisfactory ratings on
            performances by both the Bank and Borrower. This experience
            suggests that more attention needs to be given to the
            sequencing of reforms. The Poverty Reduction Support Credit
            (PRSC) program was perhaps too overloaded with
            "politically-sensitive" reforms, i.e., public
            sector, welfare, labor, and land reforms; rather a more
            phased approach could have been more manageable. Thus,
            further consideration should also be given towards ensuring
            wide-base political support for key reforms, and avoid
            interruptions every time there is a change in government.
            This is why governments need to be encouraged to pursue
            reforms that have bipartisan support, i.e., to enhance
            consultations with relevant stakeholders, including within
            government. Other lessons address the recent poverty
            numbers, which show a sharp increase in inequality between
            1990-91 and 2002, also reinforcing the importance of
            focusing on pro-poor reforms, e.g., welfare reforms and
            rural development, to be the center of the second PRSC
            operation. Moreover, it is important that future PRSC
            operations be closely linked to the budget, and, given the
            difficulties in passing legislative changes, should legal
            changes be included in the program, careful consideration
            needs to be given to the constitutionality of the proposed
            legislations, and whether they could withstand court
            challenges. Unfortunately, while this operation did
            (substantially) achieve its objectives, the results are much
            less satisfactory than they would have been if the intended
            complementary reforms, originally planned to be supported in
            subsequent operations, had actually materialized.

repnme.cdata!: Sri Lanka - First Poverty Reduction Support Credit

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the First Poverty
            Reduction Support Credit for Sri Lanka were as follows: the
            outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, and the Bank
            and borrower performance were both satisfactory. The
            findings and implications show that the recent political
            developments reinforce the importance of linking the release
            of Poverty Reduction Strategy Credit (PRSC) funds to the
            effective implementation of up-front actions and not to
            future promises. Recent poverty numbers, which show a sharp
            increase in inequality between 1990-91 and 2002, also
            reinforce the need to focus on pro-poor reforms, e.g.,
            welfare reforms and rural development. It is important that
            future PRSC operations be more closely linked to the budget.
            In this regard, the Bank team is working with the MOF to
            enhance the policy orientation of the budget through the
            development of a medium term budget framework. To ensure the
            sustainability of reforms, the new government needs to be
            encouraged to enhance consultations with relevant
            stakeholders, including those within the government, and to
            inform the public at large of the pros and cons of reforms,
            perhaps through a more systematic communications strategy.
            Given the difficulties in passing legislative changes, which
            in Sri Lanka's context could be subject to court
            challenges, future operations will need to explore
            alternative (more pragmatic) options to achieve stated objectives.

5087055.majtheme: Public sector governance,Environment and natural resource management,Rural development,Social protection and risk management,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Sri Lanka - First Poverty Reduction Support
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The principal objectives of the
            Government's development, and poverty reduction
            strategy include securing lasting peace, accelerating
            economic growth, and strengthening governance in the public
            sector. This Poverty Reduction Support Credit (PRSC) Project
            is designed to support the implementation of Sri
            Lanka's Poverty Reduction Strategy (PRS). This
            operation, PRSC I, would be the first of a series of annual
            PRSCs within a rolling four-year horizon, overlapping with
            Sri Lanka's PRS period. Consistent with the Government
            objectives and priorities, the PRSCs would support reforms
            in two major areas: 1 ) accelerating economic growth and
            supporting private sector development; and, (2)
            strengthening governance in the public sector and improving
            the welfare system. This PRSC will help the Government in
            moving forward with the structural reforms, create
            conditions for accelerating economic growth, and send a
            strong signal to the private sector. Furthermore, it will
            foster a continued fiscal consolidation, improve public
            sector governance, and, strengthen institutional framework
            and capacity in the management of public resources. These
            developments would also lead to improvements in the
            poverty-focus of public expenditures. Nevertheless, there
            are several risks: (a) the derailment of the peace process;
            (b) a substantial deterioration of external environment; (c)
            potential for domestic political instability, since Sri
            Lanka is going through a period of political
            "cohabitation"--a President from one party, and a
            Government from another; and, (d) resistance by labor unions
            to some economic reforms. Risks however, are mitigated by
            the design of the credit, and by the Country Assistance
            Strategy (CAS) triggers.
